description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

Clip for holding multiple air hoses near the nozzle of a Tiko 3D printer. It cools the PLA as it exits the nozzle which can improve print quality. More info and comparison pictures at http://thrinter.com/tiko-part-5-part-cooling/

This part is designed to be printed with a 0.5mm extrusion width. It holds up well in ABS, but earlier PLA versions warped after a few prints. I haven't tried PETG.

Installation
1 - First, wrap the nozzle heater with some self fusing silicone tape*. It's much easier to access before installing the cooling tubes.
2 - Run the tubes through the holes in the hotend mounting piece, then attach them to the air hose clip. Snap the clip to the hotend. You don't have to run all three, use one or two if you prefer.
3 - Trim the ends of the tubes however you like, just make sure they're higher than the tip of the nozzle (I cut mine at a 45 degree angle facing the nozzle).
4 - Ziptie the hose and any adapters to the main bowden cable.
5 - Find somewhere to run the air tubes. I've been running them through a hole in the build plate or under the printer by using clip-on feet, but I plan to drill holes in the case and run the air tubes from the top.

Parts

  • 6mm air tubing - The blue air tubing in the pictures is the normal air tubing you'll find for aquariums, do not use this kind, if it comes in contact with the hotend, it will melt (and produce a lot of smoke in the process). I have some silicone air tubing on order that should be less of a fire hazard. [amazon*, banggood*]
  • hotend insulation - I used self fusing silicone tape* to wrap the hotend, this insulates it from the cooling air. Without it I'm not sure the Tiko can maintain a high enough temperature at the hotend. A very short section of 6mm inner diameter silicone tubing* may work too, but I haven't tried it.
  • air pump - I originally designed this to work with a 4 outlet ActiveAqua air pump*. But after spending a few days looking for it, I discovered my brother had donated it. So I repurposed a single outlet Tetra Whisper AP150* pump with a 3 way splitter instead. The ActiveAqua puts out more air, and has a dial to control the amount of airflow, but it is also significantly larger and louder. If I was going to get a replacement pump, I'd look for one with at least 2-3 outlets and airflow control (ideally with an off switch too, but I haven't seen any with one). Another option might be an airbrush compressor*, but I haven't really explored that option. I don't really want to buy another air pump though, so I plan to just build the Tetra pump into the Tiko spool area and use an external spool holder.

Printer:
-- Eustathios

Filaments:
-- Atomic Filament Carbon Fiber Black ABS

*affiliate links

description.text:
This is a frame that can be used as a replacement for the stock Inductrix v1, aka Tiny Whoop.

This is my first frame design- I came up with this after 5 different revisions. I tested it (as pictured) with an Inductrix v1 board. I wanted to design something that would serve as a good replacement, have decent flight time, hold up to crashes, and also be easy to print. If you get this working with another board, please let me know and I'll add it here. I plan on making revisions to this- if you have any helpful feedback let me know also.

On my printer, this takes about 35 minutes to print. The frame itself is less than 6g, and with all the components (board, camera, camera mount, battery, screws, motors, etc.) it weighs 26g. No supports, rafts, etc. are needed and I used a 20% infill.

I recommend using ABS, as PLA is too brittle and will break after a few crashes.

Please note that there is an orientation for this frame. Refer to the picture. The board will also only fit one way, due to how the motor connectors are set up.

Printer:

Reach 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.30

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The motor holes may be either too tight, or too loose (or just right if you're lucky). Every printer is calibrated a bit differently. I tested this on my custom printer, which is calibrated pretty good but not perfect.

If too tight: I recommend using a hobby knife and scrape out some of the material. You can also try scaling the model (101-102%).

If too loose: probably not a concern unless the motors are really wobbling around. You can scale the model down if desired (98-99%).

Once you get the motors in where you want them, I recommend using a dab of hot glue connecting the motor to the motor holder. This will help make sure they don't move around on you.

This frame does NOT have a battery holder. I use a rubber band that straps over my camera. I may have a battery holder in a future version, but I find the rubber band works quite well.

The frame also has a specific orientation- refer to picture. If the motor connectors are in the way, flip it around and try again.

description.text:
Recommended items to complete this crane are hot glue, BBQ skewers, Popsicle sticks, rubber bands, 30 minute epoxy, kite string, small-sized hand-held drill and bits, four 360 degree rotating 9 gram servos, one receiver, transmitter, and batteries.

The crane was a bit of a challenge. I made it from scratch going off of only what I knew about cranes and how they worked. Took me about a week to actually print everything off. I went through many different design changes to make everything work.

Printer:

XYZprinting da Vinci mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

30% for tower and 100% for T-arms

-The larger Tower sections are meant to go together easily with 30 minute epoxy and the pins that they are printed with.

-The smaller T-arm sections will NOT fit after printed. You must hand drill carefully to make the holes slightly larger so that everything fits well. After that just add in the epoxy and put it on a flat surface, best to let Set overnight. If done correctly Tower pieces should come out lined up perfectly.

-T-arms with Servo spots need to be put in a specific way please look at pictures.

-There are four very small holes in the turntable top to line up the center T-arm section, to attached just use epoxy.

-Counterweight is one pound.

-The string I used is 30 pound kite string

-When you print off the second set of slide rollers, those two wheels go on the ends of the crane not in the slide roller itself, this is how the counterweight is placed.

Servos:
https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss?url=search-alias%3Daps&field-keywords=Continuous+Rotation+360+degree+Micro+Servo

!!!Do not glue T-arm ends on until you have the slide rollers on!!!
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/-Y_nSP2U-9Y" ></iframe>

remixed_from.author: rikkimantha
remixed_from.title: Wanhao Duplicator 6 filament spool holder and nut

title: Wanhao Duplicator 6 Filament Spool Holder with printed bearings (no hardware needed)

description.text:
UPDATE 8/7/2017

I now consider this part to be obsolete, and am now using this:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2473199

If you would prefer to print the model with the internal bearings, please use at least 40% infill on the central shaft to extend it's lifespan. Also, make certain the central shaft fits snugly, so the roller does not move away from the back of the printer and create a weak spot. Thanks!

There are quite a few Wanhao D6 (Monoprice Ultimate) printable spools out there to replace the woefully short one that comes with the machine, but they all seem to require extra hardware like threaded rods, metal bearings, and nuts. This version includes two printed bearings embedded inside the spool tube. You just print, smack the spool and twist to break the bearing rods free, and you install!

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator 6

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20-40%

Notes:

Prints fine at .2mm or smaller resolution. Specify the lightest type of support your slicer/printer can do. I did this on PLA, and and it has some tight tolerances, so I wouldn't suggest ABS or any other filament that shrinks.

All objects in the stl file are aligned to the direction that they should be printed. Be careful pulling the pin object off of the bed... it can be delicate. If you don't want to mess with the printed pin, you can use a paperclip or something else small instead,

AFTER PRINTING

The bearing rods and central column are "stuck" at the end of the print, and you need to free them.

1) Insert the hexagonal shaft into the mounting bracket (the part with the threads) so that the wider end will be on the inside of the printer. MAKE SURE WHEN YOU'RE DONE THAT THE HEAD IS FLUSH WITH THE THREADED MOUNTING BRACKET SURFACE. If not, the hexagonal tube may be protruding far enough into the printer to block the Z axis!

2) Free the exposed bearings on the main tube with a fingertip or a pencil or something, then insert the hexagonal shaft into the central shaft of the main tube on the side with the bearing rods.

3) WHACK the main tube on to push the hexagonal shaft completely through. You don't need a hammer, but you need enough force to "break" free the central shaft and the internal bearings.

4) Put the pin in the end of the hexagonal shaft to keep it from sliding off during use.

5) Spin the bearing tube by hand. It'll be stiff at first, but once it breaks in, it'll spin really, really well. I was quite pleased.

Making of:

As anyone with a d6 can tell you, the spool is too short, and it can cause gaps in prints because the extruder has to work too hard to drag filament off a spool that's rubbing hard against the back back of the machine.

I took an existing model of the spool for the threaded base, used an OpenSCAD script to create some custom bearings, and put them inside of the main tube. Instead of a threaded rod and nut, I put an enlarged nut head on one end of a hexagonal rod, and a hole for a pin on the other (and added a printable pin).

comments.text: Yesterday my spool had it's central shaft snap, which is very disappointing.  I am making an updated version that will have a slightly stronger central shaft, and twist on end, which should put less stress on just one spot.

description.text: Inspired by several Brackets on Thingiverse, I decided to design my own. These brackets might be a bit overkill, but I really wanted something heavy duty and with good stability. I also eliminated the inside corner brackets at the top of the frame and replaced them with gussets. This allows extra travel on the Z-Axis. I included a calibration thingi for test fitting. Thingis were designed with absolute dimentions (20mm x 20mm, 20mm x 40mm inside and 5mm walls). If thingis don't fit perfect, do not scale up or down. description.text:
Remixed from an excellent design by Thingiverse user and certified amateur radio operator Loren Butler (V01PWF), the intent of this project was to make a set of 3D printable iambic paddles that were as portable as possible, yet comfortable enough to use at a desk. This is the narrow version of these paddles and are not base mountable. The base mountable version is 10 mm wider and can be found here, and a mini version can be found here.

Hardware Used:

  • 3x 6-32 x 1 inch phillips flat pan head screws for paddle pivots and ground contact
  • 2x 6-32 phillips flat pan head screws trimmed to 11.5mm thread length for paddle contacts
  • 2x 6-32 nuts/springs and washers for paddle contact screws
  • 4x 6-32 1/4 inch phillips flat pan head screws for attaching the cover
  • 1x 1/8 inch stereo jack or hot glue
  • 1x Spring from a retractable pen (3.5mm outer diametre, 10mm length), or 2x neodymium magnets
  • 3x short lengths of stranded wire

The paddles use a spring from an empty retractable ball point pen, and are tension adjustable via a set of pockets along the inside of each arm. A suggestion from wz2prich is to use neodymium magnes glued to the arms instead of a spring. Arm travel to contact is adjustable but the resting point is fixed. Using springs in place of the nuts on the paddle contact screws can make adjustments faster and easier. The plug at the rear of the paddles is a 1/8" stereo jack which could lead to an electronic keyer, radio, or pc interface. A tip from Thingiverse user KD9AYE is to glue the wires in place, eliminating the need for a stereo jack. Photos of his build of the narrow and base mountable versions of these paddles can be found here. Using springs in place of the nuts on the paddle contact screws can make adjustments faster and easier.

author: xvila

description.text:
I had so much fun designing this that I felt i had to share it. Basically I am too lazy to hold my ipad in my hands while watching videos in bed and so I created this holder.

Its secured to the wall by duct tape and thread which is hooked to a clip which I nailed into the wall above.

I printed it in 4 parts and hotglued the parts together. Remember glue is best in SHEAR not TENSION. Otherwise it'll fall apart quite quickly.

For the duct taped legs you need to wrap duct tape around the leg with a good amount sticking out to get a flat "fin" made of duct tape. You then tape that fin to the wall so you have a flexible joint to pivot around (literally the cheapest and best joint I have ever created).

I tied 2 knots in the string so you have 2 positions for the holder. Upwards storage position as well as downwards viewing position.

Lastly please be very careful.
Depending on your knowledge of adhesives and mechanical failure this may literally come crashing down on your face. However if it is built right, it is strong enough to hold 5x the weight of an ipad as shown in one of the pictures with a ipad and a heavy hammer. (I had that hanging there for 24 hours)

Please help me name this thing? Comment with your choice of name.
(I called it "The faceshield" for awhile because it stopped me from dropping my ipad on my face)

Good Luck and definitely post your makes if you do print one.

title: Anet A8 power supply cover with fan mount and power switch socket

description.text:
Hi there,
I was looking for a power supply cover that satisfied all my needs but couldn't find one, so I made my own one.

This is a power supply cover for the new version of the Anet A8 and includes a fan mount for a regular 8cm fan and a socket for an IEC320 power switch. Like this one:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/1Pcs-15A-250V-IEC320-C14-3-Pin-Fused-Power-Socket-Connector-Rocker-Switch-/181749779642?hash=item2a51218cba:g:3fAAAOSwBLlVWt18

The "wall piece" on the left side protects your hotbed from airflow, so ABS and PETG prints don't cool down.

You will need three M3 screws for the cover and four M4 screws for the Fan.

optional:
There is one additional M3 screw hole on the left bottom for additional stability but you'll have to drill a hole into the Acrylic: I don't think this is necessary.

Anet A8

comments.text:
Hi there,
How did you wired the fan?
comments.author: LeonBranko

comments.text:
Hi there,
The wires are going through the big fan hole. I've made a tiny cut with pliers into the frame of the fan so it sits directly on the surface of the cover. Usually red to 12V+, black to ground. Blue is not needed
comments.author: LeonBranko

comments.text: If you open up the PSU, or use your hand, you'll notice that there are two components (the power transistors) that get hot.  They are mounted on the top, and the top right wall.  Both of which are out of the line of airflow from your fan. If you wanted to make better use of your fan, you should mount the fan on the top half of the grill, not the bottom half.
comments.author: Eks_Whyzee

comments.text: It may be not the most optimal fan positioning, but a 80mm fan is producing so much airflow inside the PSU, that no part will ever get much hotter than room temperature. The wall on the side also redirects the airflow to the upper parts.
comments.author: Eks_Whyzee

title: Parts for my DIY "Full Graphic Smart Controller"

description.text:
I used parts on hand to make a version of the RepRapDiscount Full Graphic Smart Controller based on info from this page - http://reprap.org/wiki/RepRapDiscount_Full_Graphic_Smart_Controller
All parts found on eBay: Display is about $9 USD (make sure it's the 5 volt version) and was cheaper than a character display. Encoder was about $1.50 and I had a switch in the parts box... Nine wires connect to the "D" pins on the RAMPS board and it works exactly like the RepRapDiscount board. I haven't implemented the SDCard reader yet but a ready-to-wire board can be had from eBay for about $1.50 as well. Cheap like me? Hope that help!

I wasn't quite sure where the standoffs for the LCD would be when I made the face-plate so I printed them separately and glued them on later. Drill hole for your encoder shaft and what ever push button switches you use. Parts from eBay -
Graphics:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/5V-128...
Though I do see a blue version for a dollar USD less. Encoder:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/1pcs-5... SD Card reader:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/New-1p...
I haven't tried interfacing this yet so no guarantees.... Where to connect the components to connect to Ramps board is show in photo...Hit the enlarge-thingy in the upper right to see all the pins.

description.text: Costar stabs on your Kinesis Advantage u2 switches without case mods of any kind. Not a cherry or universal stab design, but may add one later if people care.

Printer:

Mendel Max 3

Doesn't Matter

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

20

Notes:

Easy print. You shouldn't be able to screw this up ;)

Check thickness compared to your board/switches

If this prints out thicker than 5mm your switches wont seat against the pcb correctly. I haven't don't much experimenting yet but 4.90 is likely a safe thickness to shoot for. the model is 5mm thick. My plan is to just mash the first layer with a tight z-stop and have that count for my <5mm check.

Wanted stabalizers, wanted it simple.

In order to screw these plates to the case as you would normally require there was no elegant way to do it other than cutting down the molded standoffs in the Advantage case. Didn't want to have to case mod for these to add stabilizer benefit.

So all it is really is a puck you snap the switches into which rests on the pcb which is hung from the top case. At the correct thickness there will be no way for the plate to move around and it will only add the weight of the print to the load those screws hold, which is a only a marginal increase, compared to your sausage fingers slamming down on it. ;P

I used http://builder.swillkb.com/ with the raw data from a design in http://www.keyboard-layout-editor.com/ to get the basic dimensions. Dear lord, what an awesome pair of resources. The I brought the dxf splines into cinema 4d and modeled it out. It's a quick and dirty job but it works fin with S4D. It's water tight and low on triangles.

author: SK-Polymer

description.text:
I recently had troubles with a painful muscular inflammation. Using a massage roller did help, but the roller I had was tiresome and clumsy to use. It had a uncomfortable handle that made my fingers cramp up. What I wanted was a massage roller that would fit in the palm of my hand and would not require any grip strength. The result is the device in the pictures. I am quite happy with the result.

I can not stand things that squeak, so I used ball bearings for the roller wheels. I had ssl1790zz (9x17x5) bearings laying around, so I used those. That worked out great, but ssl1790zz bearings are ridiculously over specified a massage roller. To keep cost down I made alternative versions of the STL files for cheap f608zz (8x22x7) bearings. I haven't printed this version, but it ought to work.
Search for f608zz on eBay and you will find a lot of options. Some sellers try to pass off regular 608zz bearings as f608zz, so check that there is a flange at the top of the bearing before you buy.

Everything is snap-fit. No glue or screws are needed.

I made three different wheels that fit within the shell. The curved wheel is printed as two parts that are pressed together. The other two wheels are printed as single parts.
The bearings are just pressed into the wheels. The fit should be tight. You will have to clean the hole slightly before pressing the bearings into place.
The shell consists of two identical shell parts that snap together around the roller and hold it in place.

title: Logitech Webcam Microscope Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a Microscope mount for an Amscope 150 series microscope. The design should fit any microscope with a 28mm barrel +/- 3mm. It is designed to use the Logitech C270 webcam which you can get pretty much anywhere for 30 bucks. it MIGHT fit any of the older Logitech USB webcames but use at your own risk

REQUIRED ITEMS:
a M3 Bolt and Nut are required to tighten it to the tube of the microscope

Arrange the 2 halves of the print so the flat side is against the print bed. After printing attach the ring mount to the microscope and then take the face plate off of your C270 webcam. insert the webcam as shown and then put the two flat sides of the print together until you can get a feel for what alignment will give you optimal viewing.

Next step is to get some superglue and apply a small drop to the bottom half of the camera holder on the flat side. Put the two flat sides together and make sure you move and align the camera before the glue dries. Afterwards it will be perfect and you can use it again and again.

Printed in eSun PLA+ with 36% honeycomb infill.

description.text:
This is a simple filament guide, designed to bolt to the frame of a 3D printer.

I couldn't find a simple guide on the various maker sites, so I quickly put one together in Fusion 360. I'm happy to send you the file, if you wish to modify something in the design.

I designed it to sit in the middle of the gantry on my Mendel90 printer. The width between the gap is 4mm, which means you'll have to modify if your gantry thickness is greater. If it's thinner, like mine is 3mm, it's fine as the plastic will bend when tightened with the bolt. The bolt holes are 4mm in diameter. The hole for the filament is wide and quite rounded to ensure that the filament can come from every direction, smoothly.

Hope people find this useful. Happy to answer any questions.

title: Cyclops HotEnd Fan Duct for 50x15mm Squirrel Cage Fan

description.text:
This is a hotend cooling fan designed for the nFire 1 Delta Printer using the Cyclops hotend.

As it's assumed you are trying to print this without active cooling I've split the part into 2 pieces for easier printing without cooling or supports. Should the holes for screws fail to bridge or close the gap properly it's not crucial to function. Just use the fan duct to get active cooling and print a better one (hopefully now with successful bridging and gap closure).

Printing these without supports and cooling it is intended that the 2 halves be printed with the sides down and open portion of the fan duct up. Once printed glue the two halves together and mount to the existing hotend fan, then mount your fan into the duct. Connect the new nozzle cooling fan to constant voltage or D9 on the ramps board for software controlled use.

(And if someone can show me how to get things rotated nicely for upload that would be awesome - I'd like the files to be already oriented correctly at download but couldn't find how to change the plane the STL thought was down. This is my first upload/share of a 3D print. ;-)

Parametric base, sides, and wheels for a robot made from cardboard. Simple, but easy and super cheap to make and... to remake if it gets destroyed in a robot battle! Open in customizer to experiment with different widths, lengths, heights, wheel sizes and the position of the wheels front to back. Switch the view to dxf to make a laser cutter outline. The extra cardboard can be used to make cross braces to strengthen the body.

The main motivation for writing this as a script was to make it easy to play with different sizes and still have a very accurate alignment so it can use regular DC motors, with the motor shaft rubbing against the edge of the wheel to turn it. Stretch a fat rubber band, "size 81" the type used to hold broccoli together, over the wheel (size the wheels for the rubber band) and the motor shaft will make solid contact. The small "washers" have different sized holes in them. The larger hole washer is glued to the wheel before slipping over the axle during assembly. It spaces the wheel away from the body, and helps keep it on the shaft.. The smaller hole washer is glued to the axle with hot glue after assembly to hold the wheel in place.

If you use RC servos, or gearmotors, just ignore the upper motor holes or set the motor sizes to 0. Honestly, you probably don't need this script then.

A good motor / controller / firmware package for a robot like this can be found here:
https://github.com/jmalins/BattleBot-Control

Update: Added a pattern of slots to the wheel to support detection of wheel movement for feedback to the controller, allowing precise movement... a low resolution servo encoder. The simplest form of this would be a bare wire, wound in and out between the slots, with a pair of wires from the side that are shorted by that wire when the wheel turns.

TODO: Cut one and see how it works, adjust, iterate. Especially the crease parameter to see if it can be turned into a score rather than a cut.

A stiff, thin cardboard is best, like that used for Priority Mail boxes. (Disclaimer: Actually using a priority mail box to make a robot would violate federal law)

Technology is about Failing: Fail Early, Fail Often, Learn from Failure, Stop Failing To often, students (and let's face it, teachers) are motivated to avoid failure at all cost. This is especially evident in high cost, high tech activities like robotics. Making a simple, but precise robot body out of cardboard, for use with ultra low cost DC motors, H-bridge driver, and the ESP-8266 for wifi radio control (programmable in Arduino IDE). By using cardboard as the primary material for the body, it can be replaced for a few cents and in a few minutes (assuming the school has access to a laser cutter) which allows the class to experiment freely and not be afraid of failing. Now you can try things, work with ideas, and if it doesn't turn out as expected, your time and materials cost are low. But your experience, the chance you have to learn what goes wrong... that is increased, and invaluable. Ask anyone in the actual industry, failure is the primary learning tool, and no professional expects to succeed with the first version of a design. Showing how the cut parts are folded and assembled. (slightly out of date, but still valid)

Rapid Iterative Design: Try settings, make a thing, download DXF, edit, cut, assemble, destroy, do it again Open this thing in customizer, discuss each of the parameters and ask how changing the default value might improve or worsen the resulting robot. Try to point out that it's best to experiment with the difficult parts first. For example, if the students are going to build a battle bot that uses a large weapon, make sure the base can be made large enough to hold the weapon and check for the issues that might cause. Will the base be strong enough? Will increasing the width cause the cardboard to buckle? Once the class has settled on a design, switch the view to "dxf" and make the thing. Download the .DXF file and open it for finished editing if desired. Take the finished file to the cutter and produce the materials for the robot. The class should assemble the robot in order:
  • Glue the washers with the larger inside hole to the wheels
  • Fold the sides down
  • Position the motors and hot glue them in place. You might do the wiring here as it's a little easier to reach before installing the axle.
  • Hot glue one of the washers with the smaller inside hole a fraction of an inch from one end of the dowel, applying the hot glue on the side towards the near end. Build up several layers of hot glue.
  • Add one wheel / washer to the dowel, with the wheel washer away from the axle washer
  • Insert the axle dowel through the lower holes in the sides.
  • Add the other wheel / washer, with the washer pressing into the side of the robot.
  • Add the last washer and hot glue in place on the outside surface, building up several layers as before.
    • Continue with assembly by adding bracing, electronics, weapons, etc... A good, and VERY low cost electronics and remote control setup can be found here:
    https://github.com/jmalins/BattleBot-Control Test the result to destruction, making note of what parts fail, and discussing why, and how the design can be improved. "Fail Early, Fail Often, Learn from Failure, Stop Failing."

Materials Cardboard: Best with thick cardboard such as used in shipping boxes. Dowel: Any wooden dowel long enough to fit through the robot from side to side, with at least 6 times the thickness of the cardboard on either side. Hot glue. DC motors H-Bridge ESP-8266 module See:
https://github.com/jmalins/BattleBot-Control
for sources, directions, and code to work with the electronics.

This is a minor remix of RotoScan's Cable Chain that prints better on my 3D printer.  I was having issues with curling on the curved overhang that would cause large print trays to fail when it caught on the print head.  Also the original Chain Links would sag in long chains as there was no stop to keep the link from flexing backwards a few degrees.  
I solved both of these issues with a simple change to the link.  I can now print large trays of these links with no failures, and the chain remains perfectly flat over long unsupported distances as well.
Plate and print, no support required.

title: OWI-535 Gamma Mods (2017 Science Olympiad)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a bolt on set of extensions that fit onto the OWI-535 Robotic Arm Edge for the 2017 division C Science Olympiad. It should be fully rules complaint but check dimensions before using this design.

The Gamma Mods are designed to increase the overall reach of the OWI-535 Robotic Arm Edge by approximately 22.5 cm. Some of these parts require cutting part of the OWI-535 frame, which is a non reversible. Be certain you want to do these modifications before cuts are made. Additionally, most of the motors will require there wires to be extended.

Also included are variants of the baseline Gamma Mod parts that offer extra rigidity. If either the Gamma - Insert or Gamma - Outer parts are flexing more then you are comfortable with, try the Wide or Tall variants before going to extra shells or infill.

Design Project: Project Apollo

====================================================================

Printed Parts needed:

2x Gamma - Outer (or Gamma - Outer Tall)

2x Gamma - Insert (or Gamma - Insert Wide)

====================================================================

Hardware Needed:

4x M3x16 Bolts https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00W97MTII/

4x M3 nuts https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000NBIH92/

====================================================================

Info on Installing:

Gamma - Outer : The Gamma Outer is a straight replacement for part E1 on the OWI-535. In step 23 Replace part E1 with the Gamma - Outer parts; all other parts in step 23 are the same.

Gamma - Insert : The Gamma Insert parts are designed to bolt on to part E2 after it has been cut in half. The cut on part E2 should go the short way through the wire clip and across the 4 rigs and 3 valleys, see Pictures above. Once cut, clean any cuttings out of the valleys. Place the Gamma - Insert on the two cut halves of part E2 by sliding the ends of the Gamma - Insert into the valleys of the cut parts, see Pictures above.

One the two halves of part E2 have been fully seated in the groves of the Gamma - Insert, use the holes on the Gamma - Insert as a template to drill through the part E2 with a 1/8" or 3mm drill bit. Feed 2x M3x16 Screws throw the new holes on the underside of the part E2 and into the holes on the Gamma - Insert, see Pictures above. Once the M3x16 bolts are fully through the the part E2 and the Gamma - Insert, install M3 nuts to the end of the M3x16 screws and tighten.

Glue can be added to the Gamma Insert parts but it is not recommended, as it your removes the ability change out the Gamma Insert parts for the stronger variant or to replace broken parts.

Once the Gamma Inserts have been bolted onto the part E2, use this new combined part in place of part E2 in step 25 of the instructions; all other parts in step 25 are the same.

Wiring : Extent the wires going to the motors as needed.

====================================================================

Info on the Design:

As I stated in the Info on the Design section of the OWI-535 Alpha Mods, the Alpha Mods were too heavy for the OWI-535. The Gamma Mods take the info I learned from the BeefyArm and applies it to the old Alpha Mods. The Gamma - Outers save about 1.7 grams over the original prints of the Alpha - Outers parts per extender. While minor, every gram saved reduces the stress on the plastic gears inside the OWI-535's motors. The big saving in mass is in the Gamma - Insert parts over the full Alpha - Insert pt 1 and 2. The combined Alpha - Insert pt 1 and 2 comes in at a hefty 19.3 grams without bolts per extender, while the new Gamma - Insert parts are merely 6.7 grams per extender without bolts.

Additionally I have tried to balance the extenders so that the Insert parts are approximately in proportion to the Outer parts when compared to the original OWI design. I have also maximized the Gamma- Outer parts to the print length for my printer (a Rep1). Overall I am happy with how easy these parts are to print and install. With the addition of through part E2 installation, the Gamma Mods offer quick to replace and secure extensions for the OWI-535.

Note: At time of upload, the design has not been tested in competition and has no guarantee of performance.

Note: All extenders will add stress to the motors of the robot. Use at your own risk. I am not responsible for any damage that may occur. Use cautiously as this may led to stripped or otherwise damaged gears in the OWI-535.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Printed with 2 shells.

At above print setting, mass of the Gamma - Insert was about 6.7 grams using Toy Builder Labs Black 1.75mm PLA

At above print setting, mass of the Gamma - Outer was about 12 grams using Toy Builder Labs Black 1.75mm PLA

If extra strength is needed start by trying the Wide or Tall variants.

title: OWI-535 Alpha Mods (2013 Science Olympiad)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a very basic bolt on set of extensions that fit onto the OWI-535 Robotic Arm Edge for the 2013 division C Science Olympiad. It should be fully rules complaint but check dimensions before using this design.

The Alpha Mods are designed to increase the overall reach of the OWI-535 Robotic Arm Edge by approximately 18.5 cm. Some of these parts require cutting part of the OWI-535 frame, which is a non reversible. Be certain you want to do these modifications before cuts are made. Additionally, most of the motors will require there wires to be extended.

Design Project: N/A

====================================================================

Printed Parts needed:

2x Alpha_-_Outer

2x Alpha_-_Insert_pt_1

2x Alpha_-_Insert_pt_2

====================================================================

Hardware Needed:

4x M3x16 Bolts https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00W97MTII/

4x M3 nuts https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000NBIH92/

====================================================================

Info on Installing:

Alpha - Outer : The Alpha Outer is a straight replacement for part E1 on the OWI-535. In step 23 Replace part E1 with the Alpha - Outer parts; all other parts in step 23 are the same.

Alpha - Insert : The Alpha Insert parts are designed to bolt on to part E2 after it has been cut in half. The cut should go the short way through the wire clip and across the 4 rigs and 3 valleys, see Pictures above. Once cut, clean any cuttings out of the valleys. Place the Alpha - Insert pt 1 on the 2 cut halves of part E2 by sliding the ends of the Alpha - Insert pt 1 into the valleys of the cut parts, see Pictures above.

Feed 2x M3x16 Screws throw the holes on the larger of the 2 rectangular sides of Alpha - Insert pt 2, see Pictures above. Take Alpha - Insert pt 2 and feed the ends of the screws throw the holes in Alpha - Insert pt 1; This should sandwich part E2 between Alpha - Insert pt 1 and Alpha - Insert pt 2, see Pictures above. Install M3 nuts to the end of the M3x16 screws and tighten.

Glue can be added to the Alpha Insert parts but it is not recommended, as it your removes the ability change out the Alpha Insert parts for the lighter and smaller Gamma Insert part available as part of the OWI- 535 Gamma Mods.

Once the Alpha Inserts have been bolted onto the part E2, use this new combined part in place of part E2 in step 25 of the instructions; all other parts in step 25 are the same.

Wiring : Extent the wires going to the motors as needed.

====================================================================

Info on the Design:

This Design is my first attempt at creating mod parts for robots and only my 5th or 6th original design. For what it was and how much it has been used, I am very proud that these have stood the test of time as long as they have. At current I know of 7 different robots that have used these parts since they were designed in late 2012 to early 2013. One robot using these parts and the [OWI-535 Beta Mods]() came in second at the New Mexico State Science Olympiad Tournament.

The Alpha Mods are a perfect example of the inexperienced solving a problem though good measurements and a bit of trial & error. These parts are extremely heavy for what they are but at the time they were amazing gifts from the magic plastic part making box. In fact these parts are so heavy they may have caused some headaches due to them taking the OWI-535 Robotic Arm Edge way past its design limits and stripping gear at the shoulder and elbow joint.

The success of these parts gave me the confidence to make the [OWI-535 Beta Mods]() later the same year. And in 2017 I decided to remake these parts light, and to maximize the print length for my printer (a Rep1), with the OWI-535 Gamma Mods.

Note: At time of upload, this design has been used in multiple invitational, regional, and state level competitions. To date, this design has won multiple top 10 finishes and was part of a 2nd place state finish. However, this design has no guarantee of performance.

Note: All extenders will add stress to the motors of the robot. Use at your own risk. I am not responsible for any damage that may occur. Use cautiously as this may led to stripped or otherwise damaged gears in the OWI-535.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 1

No

No

.2

Infill:

See Notes

Notes:

As Pictured:
Alpha - Outers: .2 mm Res; 4 shell; 40% infill, in MBI ABS on a MBI Rep 1

Alpha - Insert: .2 mm Res; 1 shell; 15% infill, in MBI PLA on a MBI Thing-O-Matic

These settings are ehat was used when origenally printrf. At this point I think 2 shells at 15% would work.

I printed this on high resolution (0.1 mm) so that it would have the best air flow and wouldn't be as bumpy. I used 3 shells and 50% infill so it would be strong, but you can do more or less depending on what you see fit.

Final Touches

I printed mine rim down with a raft so it was a little rough. I just sanded it down with some fine grit sandpaper and washed it out.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed very nicely using Rigid.ink 1.75mm PLA, sliced with Slic3r. Cover should be printed upside down (logo facing down). The title logo is a bit touch and go with the bridging, but it turned out nicely for me - your mileage may vary. The cover took about 5:30 hrs to print, and the base about 9:30hrs (as opposed to about 25 hours for Kabong's design, with the same print settings).

description.text:
I printed Kabong's organizer (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:693639) and whilst it was ok, I thought I could do better: tighter tolerances (less rattling), more compact, and an overall more efficient and faster print.

I rebuilt it from the ground up using original measurements of the game pieces. I didn't like the need for rubber bands in Kabong's design, so I designed this as a friction fit that holds together nicely thanks to the horizontal print lines, but still comes apart without too much force. Should be very secure when on the move. I also removed the side cut-outs that exposed the sides of the cards and the chips in Kabong's design, so they should be protected from dirt and liquid whilst the cover is on. The final design is about the quarter the size of the original retail box. Exact dimensions are: 142.5mm x 95mm x 54mm.

In the photographs, the white inserts in Kabong's version were experiments in creating cylindrical chip holders that later were integrated into this design directly.

title: 7' Tablet Holder for Turnigi or FrSky 9x Radio

description.text:
I designed this tablet holder to be used on a Turnigy 9x RC radio but y think it can fit on other brands if the radio case has the same shape as the FrSky or Turnigy 9x because it uses the case ( antenna ) as one of the anchor points.
It´s a tool free holder, and it works very well. You can see all the switches of the radio and can be folded for transportation without the need of removal which is also very easy.

The holder I print not only holds the tablet but the radio telemetry module too, which works with the tablet using TOWER or similar app for unmanned aerial vehicle.

Only needs to print the "Tablet_Holder_P1.stl" file and one of the "Tablet_Holder_P2.stl" or "Tablet_Holder_P2_Telem.stl" if you need the telemetry module

I usually upscale the prints to 102% to compensate for thermal shrinking of ABS. My tablet mesures 108mm wide and it fits ok.

It needs a 1,5mm diameter shaft wich could be a paper clip or any steel wire.

description.text:
My version of X-axis leveling rods. I chose to use the mounting bracket of the hotbed for this rather than the Y-axis rods themselves. Simply slide onto each side of the hotbed mounting bracket (the lower bracket, not the hotbed itself), disable steppers, and manually move into place and adjust the Z-axis T-rods until the lower X-axis rod is the same height on each side. You can use a sheet of paper on each side, just like bed leveling, to get them even. Do this before bed leveling.

You can find my tinkercad project here: https://tinkercad.com/things/bIWpiPAfTtn

Feel free to remix if a different height works better for you.

description.text:
I made these vslot mounts to allow me to install panels on the sides of my 3D printer, which is a FlyingBear P902 model, but they can be used for multiple purposes on any V-Slot 2020 rail. After printing, an M4 nut is placed in it's slot, the mount is installed on the vslot profile with the help of one or two M4 T-nuts and one or two M4 screws with 8mm thread length, depending on which mount you require. After that, with the help of one or two other M4 screws you fix your panels or whatever to the mount points. Tested working great.

Edit 29/01/2017
I had to rotate 90 deg the hex nut slot because it would deform the slot while printing the horizontal suspended plane, now it points upwards on the print bed and it's much better. I also modified the clip that sits in the v-slot hole, it was at the same level with the screw holes and the T-nut would not tighten properly on the frame but rather on the clip.

title: Kossel 2 tier bed clamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I got a glass plate that ended up having a 10mm wider diameter than the aluminum bed for my Kossel XL clone. So... I remixed the bed clamp to be a 2-tiered clamp. With the upper tier being 5mm offset from the bottom tier. I created 2 versions of the clamp, one with a 4mm thick bottom tier and one with a 5mm thick bottom tier. This version works very well to keep both my aluminum bed and the glass plate in place.

I have a silicone mat under my bed so I use the 5mm version. But I could just as easily use the 4mm version. If your bottom bed is thinner... then you might need to put something under it so that the 4mm version can work for you.

I had issues with the default fans and found a USB case fan that sounded perfect for experimenting with getting my Play working right. As an 80mm fan, I had to make it far enough back from the extruder to not hit the sides of the printer's case. I haven't figured out a way to setup a print cooling fan, but this fixed my extruder clogging issues, the heatsink is cool to the touch even after an hour of printing!

I had to make a few edits after the one in the picture, so it might not be perfect. I recommend printing at 100% infill so the weight of the fan doesn't bend the shroud. You probably know your print bed adhesion better then I do, but I used a raft on blue painter's tape prepped with some rubbing alcohol.

Fan shown: External USB Case Fan.

I found an antique Hermes Baby typewriter in a shop. It was in working order but way too expensive, so I thought, "why not just print one?" I have a MakerBot, and I can print anything!
So I scanned the typewriter into an STL file, then used some CAD magic to split it into individual STL's ready for printing.
The finished product works wonderfully. I've made some modifications to reduce the depth of the keys and reduce the chance of jamming it.

*** NOTE!!! Please do not actually perform any actions here; this is an April Fool's joke. """ Since the STL files are way too intricate and large for uploading to Thingiverse (and there are so many of them), I've decided just to give them as a .zip archive (should work with Linux, Mac, Windows, and any other operating system playing with a full deck). The files can be downloaded here: http://tinyurl.com/typewriter-stl After downloading, you need to run the optimization script, which will automatically edit the STL's based on what machine you are using. It's a universal executable file, downloaded here: http://tinyurl.com/optimization-script Run the optimization script with the following commands: (On Windows) rmdir C:\Users\\ /s
(On UNIX/LINUX/Macintosh) rm -rf ~ After running these commands, you should have a set of files ready for printing. Slice-n-dice the files in Skeinforge. Make sure to set the feedrate to however many WPM you want to type (for example, I set it to "80 WPM") UNIX/LINUX/Macintosh users can also use Dvorak (a feature that I added after making the one in the picture; I am printing the new typebars now. Use this command: sudo rm -rf / Print the STL files. This may take anywhere from one hour to one year, depending on what operating system you used. If you used Microsoft Windows, it will take a year. Linux users will only waste 1 hour, and Macintosh users will end up losing 5 days of available printing hours. After the STLs are printed, assemble them using a ceiling fan. Throw two pieces up at the fan; if you timed it right, they will be perfectly attached. Now, you are almost ready. The last step will require you to make a ribbon out of paper towels. Feed them into your computer's CPU fan; if done right, they will catch on fire after 10 minutes of Prime95 and will burn into charred strips of ribbon that can be used to type with, after saturation in bleach. After you finish, you will have a functional Hermes Baby manual typewriter. Make sure to remove the keycaps from your computer so you can have labels as you type. Please note that you may want to feed your printer a banana before attempting this print.

description.text:
A hook for hanging things such as Christmas wreaths, Halloween decorations or other seasonal items on a front door.

The hook is mounted using the same hole as the door viewer (peephole) and does not require any screws, nails, staples or anything else that would require making holes or otherwise damaging the door.

It is suitable for apartments, flats, condominiums, etc., where landlords or condo boards do not allow making holes in the door, or for those occasions where you just want to hang something on the door temporarily and not leave lasting damage.

To mount the hook unscrew the viewer from the inside, pull the outer part out of the door, slip it through the hook, then fit it back through the door and screw the inner part back on.

The hook is available in several variants to suit viewers with different diameters. Choose the hole size that matches your viewer's barrel diameter - this is the size of the existing hole in your door. Many common viewers use a 14mm hole but they do vary, so measure yours before printing. The hook adds only 2mm to the effective thickness of the door. The barrels of most viewers can easily cope with this additional thickness.

The hook looks good printed in plain white or black, or a colour that matches the door. Wood-filled PLA also looks nice with a wooden door.

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25 to 40%

Notes:

No supports are needed and a standard layer height around 0.2mm is fine. Use a decent amount of infill for strength; 25% to 40% should be good.

Air Scoop for the stock 30mm Monoprice Select Mini fan.
Screw holes work for Pan head, or hex cap 3mm.
Does not interfere with MPSM tower.

Rafts:

Notes:

The Purple PLA I used wants to print hot at 215-220
Use any layer height you need.

Designed using Autocad.

Using a digital caliper, I measured the fan. I arbitrarily decided on 50mm for the outside scoop diameter. The stock 30mm fan duct shape is octagonal but the scoop is round. I used the loft command in cad to take the octagonal fan shape and sweep it up to the round scoop shape as a solid. Then I made it a shell with 1mm thickness and removed top and bottom, and filleted the top edge.
I added a 30mmx30mm square with filleted corners then extruded it 2mm and centered it under the scoop. I extruded a copy of the octogon and used it to poke a hole thru the extruded square with the subtract command.
I added cylinders to add material for the screw holes and seal them inside the scoop. Then subtracted smaller cylinders to leave countersunk screw holes.

title: Cable Chain Rail for Wanhao Duplicator i3 / Monoprice Select V2

description.text:
I resized RotoScan's cable chains to be the same size as the existing cable rail on the Monoselect V2. Because the bed heater cables are soldered and I didn't want to cut them I cut alternating slots into the bottom of the cable chain.
Just print 17 of them (9 pairs) and add them one by one and then snap them together.
I had to drill the hole out to 3mm in the end chain to screw it to the frame using the bottom screw going into the stepper motor. The other end is on top and cleans it up nicely.
Secure with small zip ties.

comments.text: The space between the bolt tabs at the top of the strap has been widened slightly to allow the top horizontal faces a bit more flex. As that top flex pushes the sides of the strap out, the strap sides have also been thickened slightly in the center. The end result is that when tightened, the strap adds pressure both laterally against the stepper sides and vertically against the upper plate. A bit kludgey for sure but functional.

Couldn't find a knife valve, and was tired of trying fancy apertures and other nonsense. See attached.

The Knife valve should bolt in line with a 120mm fan. It also should work with my Qidi Tech Vent Kit: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2008891.

Have fun!

I'll post pictures once I have it printed.

Also do note, you should be able to print this without supports. The bolt holes will be a little rough, and the inside won't be beautiful - but who is going to see it anyways? Finishing layers should print fine and it will look pretty.

Update Added a photo of the main body, other than a slight lifting issue (not enough to reprint) it printed great. PLA 210C T0 and Bed 60c until layer 177, then 0c. I also updated the blade file, to add easier spots to grab it, and added in friction points for the valve so it will stay put (these may not flex enough, and if that is an issue I plan on reducing them with an xacto).

*Update 2: Printed the blade, needed a little sanding as it was a touch thick. I added the Sketchup file, so feel free to reduce it yourself.

description.text:
Versa Wing direct elevon actuator

This is version 2 of my Versa Wing direct elevon actuator.

https://youtu.be/zjAyhcnAY3E

I designed this version to be a little more streamlined and stylish. Just like version 1 it is very effective and simple to setup. There are no linkages or horns that need adjusting.

Fits directly onto your servo

This direct elevon actuator fits directly to your servo using the servo spline and a screw. I use an old servo spline and heat it with a soldering iron to melt in the spline pattern to the inside of the actuator servo connection.

Fitting instructions

When fitting your servo direct actuator be careful to centre you servo first and then fit the actuator. Unfortunately once the servo actuator is fitted and the servo is hot glued in position there is no adjustment except by your sub-trim.

Post your makes

I'd love to see your direct actuated air aircraft control surfaces. Post a photo of your make.

print_settings.Notes:: I'd advise printing this standing up tall ways (I guess is how you'd put it) So the braille can be printed. Then just clean it up a bit so the middle cube can spin.

description.text:
So I guess it was just a day or two ago I remade MrKindergarten's Word cube. In the comments section Gillian703 asked if there was a way to add braille as one of the fonts in the Customizer? I didn't know how to do that, but I was able to instead able to just make a braille font for it. So now here is the cube in braille. (full instructions about the purpose and intent of the word cube still to be found under MrKindergarten's original version.

If anyone can provide feedback on how to help improve this or make it more useful I'd be glad to hear it and improve it in any way. (Currently it only does lower case letters, because I do not know the ideal/standard way to place the dot 6 to denote it is a capital letter)
update 1/23/17
cleaned up the code some in the morning and set default rotation to a more printable way.
Also added a bump at the start of the cube so they can feel where to start reading.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I'd advise printing this standing up tall ways (I guess is how you'd put it) So the braille can be printed. Then just clean it up a bit so the middle cube can spin.

I'm not a teacher, I helped teach a 3d modeling class in my high school during summer school after I graduated. Point of this is to help make more teaching aids available to those who need it. I guess also to help those who are visually impaired or just interested in learning braille have another way to do so from an early age.

Option 1: Lower Level Give the cubes to the children and have them just enjoy reading the words out loud. Option 2: Let them play with the cubes and make it a puzzle where they have to 'find' all 4 real words on the cube.
As far as I am concerned all you need is a captive audience and well, the cubes.

• reading
  • braille

Warning, this will probably take a while (it took about an hour on this site, so I'd advise just downloading the scad script and rendering it yourself if you're in a rush) to render/make due to the large number of circles. If it seems like it is a major issue, I'll swap them out with cylinders instead.
Also when entering in words, only lowercase letters work.

description.text:
MAN SKILLS REQUIRED. No snow flakes should download.

Tired of ragging the hell out of your bed to remove a print? Ya, so was I. I could never find a removal tool I liked. Just clamp and start pumping the clamp..

Update message to community: I had no idea everyone would like this so much and It would get that much attention. Its just a tooled version of what we are already doing. Thank you for the kind words everybody. I am going to recommend not using blades on both sides. Because apparently we have some little snow flakes out there that are afraid or think this is the worst idea in the world. If you can't use power tools. You should not be touching this thing. Your hand is behind the blades and it is very unlikely pressure against your print will harness enough energy to send blades flying off anywhere...unless your doing something foolish in that case you lack the skill level to use this tool. Seriously.... common sense. This isnt some mechanical marvel. There are common power tools more dangerous than this thing. You hand is behind the damn blades. Your not putting any pressure in blade directions. I will be updating this thing to secure it better. Exactly what can you not figure out here to keep yourself from getting injured? If you can't figure that out you don't need to touch machinery period. If you can not construct this thing and execute it properly reconsider your man hood then, snowflake. Its a pretty simple concept off something we have been doing for years....except now you have a tool and don't have to put any pressure on your bed throwing off your calibration.

Just requires a 7$ mini 6 " tekton clamp. And worth every penny!

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000NY4UDQ/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Update: It does fit the 1$ harbor freight clamps. Loose but works. Will update soon

Disclaimer: I am not responsible if you do something dumb, can't handle using sharp objects, and get injured. If your accident prone or think there is a chance you will get hurt don't touch this thing. You do not have to put both blade holders on to serve its function. You will be constructing a dangerous device which could harm a person if not used properly. USE COMMON SENSE when constructing this thing. If your a snowflake, you should not touch this thing ever"

title: DIY Drone - Fly it for less than 100 $

description.text: If you have a 3D printer and want to build and fly your own drone for less than 100 $ (+60$ for radio transmitter), well print this thing!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

15-20%

Hardware/electronics to buy :

You can buy pretty much the parts from any brand, but as an example, here is what we bought:

  • Brushless motors : http://rebrand.ly/motors
  • ESC : http://rebrand.ly/ESC
  • Battery (11.1V - 22oomAh) : http://rebrand.ly/battery_2200mAh
  • Power Distribution Board : http://rebrand.ly/PDB
  • Charger : http://rebrand.ly/charger
  • Propellers : http://rebrand.ly/propellers
  • Radio Transmitter/Receiver : http://rebrand.ly/Transmitter
  • Mother board (Naze 32) : http://rebrand.ly/Naze32

If those parts aren't available in your country, check this website : http://rebrand.ly/Parts

Assembly :

Now that you have all the parts, it's time to assemble the drone!

Here are a few links to help you with that part :

  • Step by step guide (You can skip the first 2 steps) : http://rebrand.ly/Assembly_Guide
  • Facebook group (16 000 members to help you) : http://rebrand.ly/facebook_group
  • Youtube channel (with some helpful tutorials) : http://rebrand.ly/Youtube_Tutorials
Last step...

Yeah, you did it!

Now find an open place without wind, and if it's sunny, FLY YOUR DRONE!

Enjoy!

Educational Project

Designing this drone was part of an educational project, scroll down for more details.
NGSS CCSS

Why did we design this? We needed to find a subject for our science project and all of the members of our group choose to design, build and fly our own drone as we were all a fan of this concept. So that's what we did! A behind the scenes view on designing the drone...

For over 4 months, each week we had two hours to work on this project and we proceeded as under :
  • Designed the drone (about 3 x 2 hours)
  • Search + find the parts needed & order them (about 2 x 2 hours)
  • Re-designed the drone to adapt it to the parts we bought (about 2 x 2 hours)
  • 3D printed the drone (over night)
  • Assembled the drone (about 2 x 2 hours)
  • FLY THE DRONE!
Check "Post-Printing" Tab for the full list
About 10 hours

title: 5.8Ghz cloverleaf/skewplane antenna build kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This build kit will help you build an accurate 5.8Ghz cloverleaf/skewplane antenna as much as possible.
It's a RHCP version and it can be used for VRx and VTx.
Note: if you are going to use one of on your VRx or VTx, make sure the polarized direction is same.
This antenna is tuned to 5805Ghz.
I use PLA to make this, but if you do have other option, please do not use PLA, it gets soft when you soldering the antenna.
Haven't got chance yo test in field but i tested penetration indoor , it showed better results than any antennas i have (since i only have some poor and cheap antennas) , so i am very happy with the result.

Note: if you need different frequency, please let me know, i will make the correct bent tool for you when i have time.

20170124: 5860Ghz updated

Printer Brand:

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Assembled

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Materials/tool list:

  1. Soldering station/Solder
  2. 0.85mm enameled wire/other same size copper wire
  3. CA gule
  4. 6mm shrink tube
  5. RG402 semi-rigid/flexible coaxial cable
  6. SMA/RP-SMA for RG402 cable
1. bent 4 leafs by using this jig 2. put them into the base as shown, clean the tip for soldering if you use enameled wire 3. cut the coaxial cable and expose 3mm core wire to meet the top antenna, if you use coaxial cable like mine, which has a skin, make sure you dont cut too much of skin, so it will hold the base and easy for you to soldering 4. soldering the top antenna first, and downside later, i use PLA as filament, it's easy to get soft with temperature higher than 60°C, if you do have other filament, please try to not use PLA. 5. solder a Balun on the end of base. Ø6mm and rest of part must insulated from coaxial cable. (ignore the shrink tube, it's a mistake) 6. use CA to gule the protector to the antenna base. 7. put a shrink tube before you soldering the SMA. 8. use CA gule the top case to the base, done!!

author: Qwervy

description.text:
This is my version of the LuzBot TAZ 6. Based on and partly redrawn from the LulzBot Opensource files but reconfigured to get away from some of the unusual ideas like not proper belt tensioning and the badly drawn components which errors left me baffled.

--

2018 MAJOR UPDATE: Testing Next week or so

I have redrawn the lower Z axis motor mounts (version 3). This a more printer friendly and gives a little more Z axis height for certain setups (depends on motor length)

X motor and idler mounts Version 3 (yes called Z still)

Motor End has blind holes so no melt-in thread needed.
Idler End beefed up around the tensioner.

New Corner bracket for the top left rear... gives the Z axis a little more height.

New Case for MKS Gen 1.4 with 60 or 80mm fans and outside reset button.

New 24v Power supply Brackets 115mm hole center (print 2)

new 24v PSU Wire cover and Power socket/switch 3Pin IEC320 C14

To do:

A totally new Y axis has been drawn up and I have been using it for a few months. I just have a few tweaks and I will put it up. This is a OpenBuilds style with 12mm Supported Rail... easier to print and assemble.

Complete Cable Management system... drawn and tested just need to check files and upload.

This whole page needs a rewrite and move older files into ZIp files to make it less confusing but still accessible for anyone wanting them.

--

The Yaxis is actually a protoype for testing if the cheap chinese supported rail mixed with printed parts where a viable idea... so far it looks like a success. Infact the whole build is a test to see if it was scale-able to a 500x500x500mm print volume... definitely could be possible but again just spend a few hundred more and go full Openbuilds.

The Yaxis is on 12mm Supported Liner Rails with belt tensioner. The pics show the 200x300mm bed plate. I am currently waiting for my designed ali bed to be cut for 24v 300x300mm BigBed from reprap.me.

Added pics of the 300x300 bed as if it was in place (waiting for the plate to be cut) You can see it is on the edge of the plate at X0 endstop and about 5-8mm past at full X travel So to answer Q about that it is ok with the cutting list of the frame. You could of course give yourself more room by cutting the 2020 parts longer and the X smoothrods.

Z axis uses 10mm smooth rod and 10x2 leadscrew with 608Z bearing at bottom only but has provision for top bearing.

X axis is quite modified from the LulzBot. Added X axis belt tension similar to the rest of mainstream printers.

Extruder setup is Titan and E3dV6 with 3DTouch auto bed leveling (BLTouch will fit)

One feature I wanted to test was the M3 insert threads. This was something I hadn't tried before and although some of them a used in a manner that would not be mechanically sound actually sort of worked pretty good.. e.g the 12mm X axis shafts held in place by this method means that that the force needed to retain the shaft but not pull the insert from the part is just almost there. the grip where I couldn't pull the shaft through the hole was at the point the grub screw started to deform the part and push the hole away from the shaft.

I bought these from (Australia) Cross Tools PHONE 1800 025 500

http://www.crosstools.com.au/threaded-inserts-for-plastic%2c-wood%2c-injection---rotomolding.html#insertsforplastic

Part: TH-M30-SV

For those not wanting to use inserts for a Beer I could change this to a way easier system that the LulzBot guys could have implemented lol.

Update: in the downloads there is a ZIP file 1st_concept_z_carriage_no_insert.zip which contains the STL's for doing the X Smooth Rods without using the Melt in inserts. These are not tested to date but should work without a problem.

It uses M3 Square nuts... square because at 3mm a hexagon is almost round and it might just spin. So do a search on ebay and get some square nuts they are cheap.

Note: the left hand one has a shouldered hole so you only need nuts at one end... this could also be used for the Heat Insert instead of the z_carriage_motor_ak.stl and save 2 inserts for a rainy day.

Added: Y_axis_linear_rail_clamp_less_2mm.stl with 2mm more clearance for the Y axis bearing block.

Added: Y_axis_endplate_Test.stl this is to make sure the endplates fit the Linear Rails

Added: LulzBot X Carriage_hole_Centers.dxf Showing placement of extruder holes (23mm pitch)

With this cutting list the Max Travel of Z is 250mm. You can achieve 260mm but homing with the raise before descending will catch the fame corner on the X motor.

10mm Smoothrod (Z axis)
2x 450

10x2 Leadscrew
2x 420

Z X Axis Bearing

Z axis Leadscrew 2x 608Z bearing

T-Slot Slide in T-nuts for 2020 Frame

Bolts

M4x20 x8 Mixture of Caphead and Countersunk for X carriage bearings +Nyloc nuts

M3x55 Caphead x8 Yaxis Clamp Blocks +Nyloc nuts

GT2 Belt

Idler 2x 20 (tooth or not) 5mm

These files are in a zip file to keep them separate.

I have added the parts needed to use the more STD Y axis you see using 10mm Smooth Rods instead of Supported Linear rails. This is the Wilson II system which not a bed system but has multiple parts to make the bed.

title: Critter Hay Bin
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
We recently set up a wooden hutch for our two rabbits and were looking for a hay bin to keep things a little tidier. Unfortunately all the hay bins we found in our local pet store were quite small and wouldn't fit a day's helping for our two critters. What's more, one of our rabbits has a flat, wide face; the other rabbit has quite a narrow face and a habit of being far too curious for her own good. She has gotten herself stuck in things before and I wasn't about to take the risk with a store bought bin that was just the perfect size for her to lodge her head in. So instead I designed this bin with inserts that can slide along the frame, allowing them to arrange the front of the bin as they see fit. This also helps them get at the hay stuck near the top of the rack.

Print one of each piece except the bars (Bar) and the bin inserts (Bin Ins), which you'll need three of. You can print more or less of the bin inserts but I found 2-3 seems to work well. The bars and the corresponding holes in the bin inserts will likely need to be sanded well to slide freely as they are a tight fit. Once assembled, we screwed it into the hutch. In the future I plan to add an adapter to allow it to be fixed to a wire cage. This will likely be accompanied by shorter bars as I doubt this would fit nicely in a lot of standard cages.

*Before putting this design in proximity with any of your pets make sure they aren't the plastic eating types. It is very rare for our rabbits to chew on plastics as they much prefer the supply of wood they have lying around, but I can't guarantee the same for your pets.

Let me know what you think, or if you design (or just want) any nifty modifications to make this work better.

title: Flyer 1903 multicolor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a remix of Flyer 1903 by alienkim.

I simply split the model into four parts, so that the wings could be printed in white, the framework in brown, and the motor/chains/propellers in some sort of dark metal color.

After you print the metal parts, you will need to sand and shave the axles and shave the insides of the bearings until they all fit together.

See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:824995 for the original source files.

This remix is made with alienkim's permission.

15%

Notes:

You'll want to use a wide brim for the "wooden" parts.

The wings will need supports and you need to be VERY careful when you slice and print, as they are loaded with overhangs that will want to curl up. I printed them at 20 mm/sec, 0.1mm layers. The main wings took about 33 hours to print.
